Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Energy production, transportation and utilization are ubiquitous in the United States. They encompass nuclear and chemical processes that are subject to a multitude of failure mechanisms that can be the result of poor design, human error or acts of nature or terrorism than can have catastrophic impact of life and property. The disaster mitigation system being constructed in this activity is a system of systems that provides emergency response staff with both training and planning as well as real time guidance on effective strategies to protect the general public and first responders. The system uses computational fluid dynamics to predict toxic plume evolution and an intelligent agent based model of the impacted population operating within an intelligent traffic management system. Cognitive algorithms are being developed to analyze the output data and dissect it to channel necessary information and guidance to the appropriate people. These analyses use high performance parallel computing to create the necessary integrated solutions and exploit many of the features of the Global Environment for Network Innovations (GENI) network. This will result in simulation based information and guidance that can be quickly, and reliably, transmitted to an emergency operations center and first responders in the event of a large toxic material release in an urban area. A pilot exercise will be performed in collaboration with an urban emergency response team to demonstrate and explore what might be achieved during an emergency to mitigate adverse effects using such emerging advanced computing and networking capabilities and thus encourage their use.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Economics and convenient access to services continue to drive extensive urbanization across the US. This results in an increasing number of urban areas with large numbers of people at risk of major losses in life and property in a natural or man made disaster (Figure 1). However new communication networks, including multifunctional mobile device networks, are now being routinely installed and expanded regionally by commercial interests. These offer relatively a low cost means to acquire real time data and communicate with the population at risk. This in turn allows timely use of powerful computational and data analysis tools. Such tools can provide enhanced situational awareness and decision support to the emergency responders and forecasts on how the emergency might develop in the short term as the adverse event evolves (see Figure 2). A key to acquiring, analyzing and communicating results in real time is a very high-speed resilient communication network. In the this study the novel attributes of an advanced research network, Global Environment for Network Innovation (GENI), were employed and evaluated as a link between a model emergency operations center and a data analysis center, in much the same way it would be required in an actual emergency. This is illustrated in the attached functional diagram that shows the disaster mitigation system (DMS) under development by the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga (UTC) and SimCenter Enterprises, UTC’s not-for-profit affiliate, that was used to generated realistic disaster databases.  These databases were the output from DMS for a detailed time dependent simulation of the release of a toxic gas within the cities of Washington D.C. (shown in Fig 2) and Chattanooga, TN. Motor vehicle traffic within the city of Chattanooga was also included (see Figure 3) as was the local weather conditions in both cities. In the Washington simulation the effect of both a car bomb and a backpack type explosive device were also considered.

The files thus obtained were transmitted to and from UTC through a prototype GENI network node (ProtoGENI) at the University of Kentucky to a similar prototype node at the University of Utah and data rates measured. Special software was written to facilitate the operation and the slicing and software programmable networking capabilities of ProtoGENI utilized.  It was concluded from these results that in its present stage of development the ProtoGENI, while showing considerable promise, lacked the immediate access and dedicated resources required in an emergency to utilize its full potential. Further research will be required to allow this immediate access yet maintain network security. It also appears that further research will be required to reduce the computational time required to provide the decision support information.

None of the deficiencies appeared fundamental and hence it is anticipated that these problems will be eliminated as GENI evolves.
